awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Skills, Majors, and Jobs: Does Higher Education Respond?
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid technical progress leads to skill obsolescence, yet educational institutions and students are slow to respond to these changes in the labor market. This research project will use a large data set on changes in skill demand and college enrolments by major and the content of majors to investigate two interrelated questions: (i) what skills are associated with each college major and how does skill demand vary over time and space? (ii) how do higher education course-offerings and student course-taking respond to changes in demand for skills? The research will be based on data on all job postings over a time matched with data on all course offering (and their content) in a state. The results can help institutions respond to skill demand by rapidly changing the content of their curricula and educational policy makers plan better. The results will also help guide students not only in their choice of majors but also the courses and skills they choose to acquire in their chosen majors. By providing inputs into policies that align skill needs and skill training in a rapidly changing technological work place, this research will help US educational institutions provide the skills the economy needs, hence lead to rapid economic growth and improved well-being of Americans. 

This project will use merged data from the Burning Glass project and the Delaware Cost Project which has department level panel data on credits, courses and faculty as well as individual level data on student course taking, quasi-experimental methods and machine learning techniques to investigate how college students and college administration respond to changes in labor skill demand. Specifically, it investigates what skills are associated with each college major, how within major cross-major skills demand differ across space and through time, and how skill investment responds to changes in skill demand in the labor market. Previous studies have focused on the demand side of skill acquisition; this project will however look at how skill supply (by university providers and students) respond to changes in skill demand by exploring several aspects university curriculum that makes these supply responses possible. The quasi-experimental methods permit causal identification of the effect of changes in skill demand on human capital investment. The project will explore differential responses at lower-division, upper-division, and graduate levels. The results of this research will provide guidance on policies to align skill investment to changes in skill demand and in so doing will provide the needed skills and lead to faster economic growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Steven Hemelt, Brad Hershbein, and Kevin Stange have completed research for their NSF-sponsored project, “Skills, Majors, and Jobs: Does Higher Education Respond?” (NSF Award #1919387). Research conducted for this project examined whether and how students and institutions of higher education respond to changes in the skills demanded by employers.

 

In order to answer the larger question that motivated our project—whether institutions and students respond to changes in skill demand—we first needed to develop a better understanding of (a) the relationship between programs of study in college (i.e., majors) and skills requested by employers; and (b) the labor markets in which specific colleges and universities operate, in terms of flows of graduates. We wrote and published two papers that address these initial steps. The first paper used detailed job ad data from across the United States to systematically characterize the relationship between granular skills and college majors (Labour Economics, 2023). The second paper collected data from a professional networking platform to describe the institution-specific destinations of college graduates (between 2010 and 2018) from nearly all public and private non-profit institutions in the United States. We then used this new dataset to illuminate features of the market college graduates, including an analysis that finds support for the notion that one way colleges and universities may promote upward economic mobility for students from low-income backgrounds is through the strength of the labor markets to which an institution typically sends students (Journal of Policy Analysis and Management, forthcoming). We made these data publicly available through OpenICPSR, and many researchers, policy analysts, and journalists have made use of these data for local reports and exploratory analyses.

 

Building from these initial research products, we next wrote a paper that explores whether and how human capital investment responds to changes in labor market skill demand, specifically within the 4-year sector of higher education in the United States. Four-year universities are often criticized for their relative inattention to labor market needs, and there is less empirical evidence on their responsiveness to such demands, compared to 2-year colleges. Our paper develops a new measure of institution-major specific labor demand, and corresponding shift-share instrument, that combines job ads with alumni locations (NBER Working Paper 31572). We find that postsecondary human capital investments meaningfully respond. We provide evidence that the magnitude of the overall response depends on both student demand and institutional supply-side constraints. Our findings illuminate the nature of educational production in higher education.

 

On the policy side, our findings have contributed to state-level discussions about “brain drain,” the responsiveness of higher education to labor demand, and student success more broadly. We have written several policy briefs that summarize the core findings or key insights from the research products above in high-level ways for policymakers and practitioners. Moving forward, we will continue to engage policy leaders in conversations about our work and its potential implications for higher education policy decisions.

 

References

 

Conzelmann, J. G., Hemelt, S. W., Hershbein, B. J., Martin, S., Simon, A., & Stange, K. M. (2023). “Grads on the Go: Measuring College-Specific Labor Markets for Graduates.” Journal of Policy Analysis and Management, forthcoming.

 

Conzelmann, J. G., Hemelt, S. W., Hershbein, B. J., Martin, S., Simon, A., & Stange, K. M. (2023). Skills, Major, Jobs: Does Higher Education Respond? NBER Working Paper 31572.

 

Hemelt, S. W., Hershbein, B., Martin, S., & Stange, K. M. (2023). College majors and skills: Evidence from the universe of online job ads. Labour Economics, 85, 1-17.
